title: Standard Form
text: The standard form of a quadratic is as follows: $$f(x)={a\left(x-h\right)}^2+k$$
speech: The standard form of a quadratic is as follows:  f of x is equal to a, parentheses x minus h,  squared plus k
pacedSpeech: The standard form of a quadratic is as follows:   f of x is equal to a,  x minus h,  squared plus k

title: Finding $$h$$
text: We can find $$h$$ by using the formula $$\frac{-b}{2} a$$. $$\frac{12}{2}=6$$. Thus, $$h=6$$.
speech: We can find  h  by using the formula , fraction, negative b, over 2,  a .  12 halves is equal to 6 . Thus,  h, is equal to 6 .
pacedSpeech: by using the formula  , fraction, negative b, over 2,  a

title: Finding k
text: We can substitue $$x=h$$ into the general form of the quadratic to find k. $$6^2-\operatorname{12}\left(6\right)+32=k=-4$$.
speech: We can substitue  x is equal to h  into the general form of the quadratic to find k.  6 squared, minus 12 of 6 plus 32 is equal to k is equal to negative 4 .
pacedSpeech: We can substitue   x is equal to h
into the general form of the quadratic to find k.   6 squared, minus 12 of 6 plus 32 is equal to k is equal to negative 4

title: Rewriting into Standard Form
text: Using the values of $$h$$ and k derived in the previous steps, we can write the equation in standard form. $$f(x)={\left(x-6\right)}^2-4$$
speech: Using the values of  h  and k derived in the previous steps, we can write the equation in standard form.  f of x, is equal to parentheses x minus 6,  squared minus 4
pacedSpeech: and k derived in the previous steps, we can write the equation in standard form.   f of x, is equal to  x minus 6,  squared minus 4
